I personally don't think this is the beginning of peak oil. Oil has been driven up lately purely on the basis of speculation.
 
 Another problem is that the oil companies have been sitting on their asses for a long time now, instead of looking for new oil. This is why the supply/demand margin has tightend so fast, which in turn makes people nervous (unjustly IMO). New oil is still out there if you look for at, as can been seen by recent finds of new oil fields in Venezuela.
 The oil companies have now realised this and are finally diverting the necessary funds for oil exploration.
 
 A lot will also depend on the worlds adaptation to new energy sources (or sometimes old ones) or more efficient ways to use energy. Coal is back in fashion, hybrid cars are becoming an everyday sight and nations all over the world are building or thinking about building nuclear powerplants. In Holland our one remaining nuclear powerplant will be held open for longer than was anticipated and we are also planning on building a massive windmill park in the sea.
 Demand for oil will go down and $ 60 or $ 100 oil will just be seen as a momentary lapse of sanity.

As anyone who's familiar with our public exchanges can testify to, commodities are the rough tough market. Futures contracts on oil are making fortunes. Just considering the daily volume in barrels makes a $1.00 gain/barrel on a big contract serious money. And it has to be acquired at least six-months before consumption to allow distribution planning. Some spot loads are traded right down to the point of tankers discharging crude at final destination after more than a dozen changes in ownership. Traders have a finite commodity in demand at near the available level of supply. They can ride it up and down and it just keeps getting better.
 
 I can't see that far out (one of the reasons I never played the commodities markets) and agree with Gamehuis, a lot of factors are involved. I don't know cost/barrel of production for new exploration, but if it offers adequate margin in the current market, I'd think it would be a priority. And I don't see oil companies rushing to spend big bucks in exploration. Everybody's happy but the end user, and that's part of the system. I think it will take a decent sized global economic slowdown to reduce what's now normal consumption and for that reason think it will be traded up as high as markets can absorb. Any guesses on what that price will be?

Looking at the way oil prices have skyrocketed I can't help but feel that we are witnessing a bubble.
 Compared to a year ago oil is up 60%. I find it hard to believe that demand and inflation are the main drivers behind this uprecedented spike. The dollar is trading at around the same levels against the Euro as last year and demand certainly hasn't increased tenfold.
 
 This spike in oil prices reminds me a bit too much of the housing bubble: prices go up too much for no real apparent reason. $ 40 - $ 50 oil was reasonable considering the devaluation of the dollar and the rise in demand, but $ 60 - $ 100 oil is just nuts.

 No value added wealth for the US in real estate or oil, actually quite the opposite. 32% of raw lumber is imported from Canada, as are most wood product composites, with no justifiable expansion in population to create greatly expanded housing starts. US oil imports are roughly 40% of consumption with a 1.3% yearly growth factor in total consumption from 2003 to 2004, not exactly earth shaking. 
 
 When growth graduations (demand) are applied, there's really no basis for the phenomenal price increases other than speculation. Now let's think about what a temporary shortage of supply, say a couple of weeks of US vehicles in long lines at refueling stations, would do to oil prices. That would be an instant $80/barrel market?

[QUOTE=georged]I don't know cost/barrel of production for new exploration, but if it offers adequate margin in the current market, I'd think it would be a priority.[/qutoe]
 
 Acceptible F&Ds (finding and development costs) for exploration wells range from $15-$25/boe depending on the project type and scope.
 
 
And I don't see oil companies rushing to spend big bucks in exploration.

 
 With prices this high, while it does take some of the risk out of exploration economically, the long turn around time for exploration projects makes them unfavourable when compared to the rapid drilling and on production times that can be achieved within producing pools.
 
 All of the drilling is simply maximizing production from known fields.
 
 We can't drill DEVEOLPMENT oil wells fast enough. F&D costs are in the $5/bbl CDN range, though the cost of steel and increase in service costs are driving that number up quickly. At any rate, if you can make $70/bbl (CDN), YOU MAKE HAY.
 
 I've got 2 rigs drilling myself, doing horizontals, with potential to add a third doing verticals, and there's no end in sight. That's 3 or 4 times the normal activity. 
 
 Stripper wells, wells that produce less than 5bbls/d, usually 1 or 2, and have high water cuts, most of them drilled in the 50s or 70s, are being turned back on and are actually economical. 
 
 These are wild times.
 
 I haven't been in the business long enough, but everyone here with grey hair is warning that it won't last, and that we are in for downturn. They just don't know when. :p
